form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
form.official-title: To authorize the reclassification of the tactical enforcement officers (commonly known as the Shadow Wolves) in the Homeland Security Investigations tactical patrol unit operating on the lands of the Tohono O’odham Nation as special agents, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Shadow Wolves Enhancement Act.

section.header: Reclassification of Shadow Wolves as GS–1811 special agents
section.text: The Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement is authorized—

paragraph.text: to reclassify the GS–1801 tactical enforcement officers (commonly known as Shadow Wolves) assigned to the Homeland Security Investigations tactical patrol unit operating on the lands of the Tohono O'odham Nation, as of the date of the enactment of this Act, as GS–1811 special agents, upon the successful completion of—

subparagraph.text: the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center’s Criminal Investigator Training Program; and

clause.text: Customs Basic Enforcement School, if the officer was hired before March 2003; or
U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement Homeland Security Investigations Special Agent Training, if the officer was hired during or after March 2003;

paragraph.text: to classify any Shadow Wolves who are assigned to the unit referred to in paragraph (1) after such date of enactment as GS–1811 special agents upon the successful completion of the training described in paragraph (1); and

to classify as GS–1811 special agents upon the successful completion of the training described in paragraph (1) any Shadow Wolves who are hired as part of a comparable unit (regardless of location) established after such date of enactment with the approval and consent of the appropriate Indian tribe.

section.text: Not later than 90 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Homeland Security shall submit to the Comptroller General of the United States, the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate, and the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives a strategy for—

paragraph.text: expanding comparable units referred to in section 2(3) to appropriate areas near the international border between the United States and Canada or the international border between the United States and Mexico, with the approval and consent of the appropriate Indian tribe.

section.text: Not later than 1 year after receiving the strategy required under section 3 and annually thereafter for the following two years, the Comptroller General of the United States shall submit to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs of the Senate and the Committee on Homeland Security of the House of Representatives—

paragraph.text: an assessment of the effectiveness of such strategy; and
any recommendations for improvements to the strategy that the Comptroller General determines to be appropriate.

attestation-group.attestation-date: Passed the House of Representatives March 8, 2022.
